dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The girl, in a WHITE DRESS, leans against the brick wall college building, smoking a rolled cigarette. It is springtime. The green lawns of the college are immaculate. A BUMBLEBEE buzzes on a clover. The girl takes another drag, and exhales a perfect SMOKE CIRCLE. Suddenly, a MAN rides up, on one of those Victorian-era BICYCLES. He’s a stiff, gray-haired professor-type, in a black coat. He nearly topples off his bike when he sees the girl.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: (indignant) What’s this?! Women are not allowed on the grounds of the college. And smoking?! The very idea... I’11 put a stop to this. Who are you? The girl looks at him, ironic, unruffled.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m nobody. Who are you. The man sputters.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: I, young lady, am the prefect. And I‘1l give you one more chance, before I have you dragged from this campus by force. Identify yourself! Who are you?! The girl, slowly, takes another drag. We push in on her f again, as she answers.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: I’m Emily Fucking Dickinson. MUSIC. Specifically, Kendrick Lamar, “King Kunta” (2015) This twenty-first century anthem of black empowerment becomes, for now, an anthem of Victorian white-girl empowerment. What, you have a problem with that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Kendrick as her underscore, EMILY DICKINSON, 25 year old, struts through the woods of 19th-century Amherst.

dialogues.speaker: KENDRICK
dialogues.text: “Bitch where you when I was walkin’? / Now I run the game, got the whole world talkin’...” As she walks, and walks, the weeds and brambles whip at t bottom of her dress, getting it dirty. The wind reddens h cheeks. Untidies her hair. KENDRICK (CONT’D) “Everybody wanna cut the legs off him / Black man, take no losses...” She looks exhilarated. But also like she could kill someb

dialogues.speaker: TITLE
dialogues.text: INT. EMILY’S BEDROOM - BEFORE DAWN Four a.m. in the mid-19th century -- dark and quiet as sh Emily wakes up in her small, creaky bed. She throws off t covers. She grabs a shawl, lights a kerosene lamp, and sits down her tiny, cramped writing desk. Takes out a pencil and a scrap of paper. Thinks. Chews her pencil. Then -- she gets into it. Writing. Writing. Lightning striking in her brain. And then -- an interruption. A KNOCK on the door. From outside, her sister’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Emily! Emily, wake up! Emily crouches, like a tiger, then explodes.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What the fuck! She slams down her pencil, bangs over to the door, opens  4. Her sister, LAVINIA, 22, plump and curvy with a gap betwe her teeth, is standing there, holding a BUCKET.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: You have to go fetch water. Emily glares at her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It is four in the god damn morning, Lavinia. I am writing. Wri-ting.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Mother says you have to go. I did it yesterday.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t Austin do it?

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Austin’s a boy, Emily! He doesn’t do chores! Emily shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: This is such bullshit. Lavinia shrugs, and hands Emily the bucket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily trudges back from the well with her bucket full of water, as the first light of day appears in the sky. She half-whispers, still trying to puzzle out her new poe

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (under her breath) “Because I could not stop for Death”... “Because I could not stop for Death”... She thinks up another line, and stops dead in her tracks. Half the water sloshes out of the bucket. She doesn’t car She puts the bucket down. Takes a little pencil and paper of her dress pocket. She scribbles.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Because I could not stop for Death - He kindly stopped for me.”  Up in a tree, a BIRD chirps. Emily smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An establishing shot of the BIG YELLOW HOUSE where Emily Dickinson spent almost all of her life. A pristine, impos New England mansion, set amongst woods and hayfields. The window up on the right is Emily’s room. This is Main Street, Amherst, 1855 -- not exactly bustlin But still, any action that goes on in the town, the Dickinsons are right in the thick of it. Now, Emily emerges from the path, with her bucket, and en through a SIDE DOOR. INT. KITCHEN —- MORNING Emily’s MOTHER, Mrs. Dickinson (think Laurie Metcalf), an Lavinia are already hard at work in the overheated kitche Mrs. Dickinson tends to a RAGING FIRE on the hearth, whil Lavinia PLUCKS A CHICKEN. As Emily enters, Mrs. Dickinson attacks her.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: We needed that water an hour ago! Where have you - oh, Emily, this bucket’s half-empty! You let it all spill out! Oh, you’re a useless girl. Useless! Emily rolls her eyes. This is obviously a familiar routin

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Can't we just get a maid? Mrs. Dickinson is appalled.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Over my dead body.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But why? We can afford one.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: It’s not for you to say what we can and can’t afford, you wicked thing.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: We own six fricking horses, Mom. We can get a maid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When your father married me, I said he was getting the best housewife in all Hampshire County. No - in all New England! I’d rather scrub the skin off my fingers than hire a maid. And I’m bringing you girls up to be just like me.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But--

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (cutting her off) You're going to make a good housewife someday, Emily Dickinson, if it kills me. Mrs. Dickinson claps some flour on her hands, and begins kneading a huge pile of dough.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now - you need to go get dressed. We have another gentleman coming to see you.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Ooh! A gentleman?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Mom, no --

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: He'll be here quite soon. So go upstairs and prepare yourself. This man could very well be your husband.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: So romantic!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (dark) I wonder what hideous deformity this one will have.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Don’t be rude. And you better not pull any stunts like you did last time.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I made an offering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You dropped a dead mouse in that poor man’s lap.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes. Like a cat.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You are not a cat, Emily!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. Tragically, I am a woman. Emily exits, but not before grabbing one of the FRESH SCO her mother has just pulled from the oven.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Those scones are for the suitor! Emily's gone. Mother shakes her head. Lavinia looks annoy

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Why don’t I get to have suitors?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I’m not trying to marry you off. You’re good at housework.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: So I have to die an old maid because I can fetch water?!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Life isn’t fair, Lavinia. The Dickinson women go back to work. INT. EMILY’S BEDROOM - DAY Emily, in her room, is sneaking another chance to work on poem. She sits at her tiny desk, and scribbles. She hasn’ changed her clothes or brushed her hair or anything. From downstairs, she hears Lavinia screaming.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Emily! He’s here! Frustrated, she slams her pencil down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Dickinson sits in the parlor drinking tea with the suitor, GEORGE. George is gawky, but cute -- a Jesse Eisenberg type. Mrs. Dickinson sips her tea, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: She’1ll be down in a moment. I do apologize.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (awkward) Oh - no worries. Now Emily makes her entrance. She has brushed her hair so that it all HANGS IN FRONT OF HER FACE. Like Cousin It. S looks like a woman walking backwards. She looks insane. She walks into the room slowly, her hair blocking her vis

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (dramatically) Hello. Mrs. Dickinson gasps.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Emily - cut that out! Emily laughs, and flips her hair back, so she can see. Th she looks at the suitor. She recognizes him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, for fuck’s sake. George?!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hey, Emily. Mrs. Dickinson is baffled.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You have already made my daughter’s acquaintance?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Mom, this is George. He’s in the lit club with Austin. We hang out all the time. Mrs. Dickinson’s hand is trembling on her teacup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well. I was just telling George here what an excellent wife you will be. How frugal and punctilious you are in all your duties--

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah - I’m a real catch. Emily flops down in an armchair and, literally, lights a cigarette. Mrs. Dickinson almost faints.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You put that out right now!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (exhaling) George, can I talk to you for a second? Outside? George leaps up, eager for a chance to be alone with her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Totally!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Cool. Mom - we’ll be on the porch. Try to relax. Emily heads outside. George follows. Mrs. Dickinson looks at the ceiling, praying for help.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily leans against the porch railing, and takes out anot cigarette. George scrambles to light it for her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What are you even doing here, George?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see you. (Beat.) I always want to see you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You know I’m not going to marry you, right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Never say never, Emily. Like you wrote in your poem - “I dwell in Possibility.”  10.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Nice. I love when people quote me.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why won’t you marry me? I’m not good enough for you?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You don’t understand - I’m not going to marry anyone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That’s not what your mother says.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I have one purpose on this earth, George - and it is to become a great writer. A husband would put a stop to that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You say that now, but little by little, you would. Emily stubs out her cigarette. George grabs her by the wr

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I’m madly in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well - too bad.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is there someone else?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Actually - yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Who is he? I’1l kill him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You can’t kill him. He is Death.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?  11.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That's right. I’m in love with Death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black carriage pulled by white horses rolls up in front the Homestead, in the moonlight. Emily waits for it, at t bottom of the steps.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: He takes me out for a carriage ride, every night. He’s a total gentleman. A silver fox. Sexy as hell. The carriage stops, and a HAND reaches out. Emily TAKES T HAND, and climbs in. The carriage rolls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George shakes his head, in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're such a fucking weirdo. Why am I so attracted to you? Emily smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd do anything for you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well... there is - something - you could do.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Name it. Emily reaches into the pocket of her dress.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're still editor of the lit mag, right?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well - co-editor - but yes.  12. Emily pulls out a piece of paper, and hands it to him. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I want you to publish this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Whoa! Awesome! You're finally gonna let me publish one of your poems?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well - I’ve rewritten it forty times - I’m still not sure it’s ready, but...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: This is perfect timing. We have a little space in our newest issue - I can sneak this in. It goes to print tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Really?! Tomorrow?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Okay - but wait.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You can’t print my name.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? Why not? Emily looks over her shoulder. Paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: My father doesn’t approve of women publishing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, come on. That’s stupid. You’re a genius, Emily - he has to approve of that. A TAPPING on the windowpane interrupts them. Emily looks sees Lavinia inside, waving at her to hurry up and come i

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Couldn’t you put my initials or something? Or like - anonymous.  13.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No way. You deserve credit. And you should stand up to your father. Emily’s silent, thinking this over. Then she smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You know what? Fuck it. You’re right. Publish it, with my name and everything. Thank you, George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (pocketing the poem) Any time, Miss Dickinson. George leans forward, and KISSES Emily on the lips. Then, hops over the porch railing, and takes off, down the lawn Lavinia, through the window, makes a kissy-kissy face at Emily. Emily sticks a finger in her mouth like, gag me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily marches back into the parlor, where her mother and sister are cleaning up.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That was a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes, Emily, you ruined it again.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: She didn’t ruin it! They were kissing! I saw!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (scandalized) Kissing?! My god! What is wrong with you?!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You're the one who keeps throwing me at these men!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I’m not throwing you--

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes you are! It’s humiliating! You'd pawn me off on a widower, a cripple - anyone who would take me! (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The whole town of Amherst knows how bad you want to get rid of me! At this moment, Emily’s father, EDWARD DICKINSON, appears the doorway. As soon as he enters the room, the energy changes. He’s i charge of this family - a bona fide New England patriarch a top hat and tails. Mr. Dickinson can be tough, even harsh, which is why it w be great if he was played by someone adorable (say, Bob Balaban). He loves his daughter Emily enormously, but the relationship contains much darkness and complexity. Now, he regards his wife and daughters the way a farmer m look at some chickens.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What’s all the fuss?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Mother’s trying to disown me again.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You're twenty-five years old, Emily! I was married at eighteen - it’s high time for you to find a husband!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: And move out, you mean!?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Well yes, that is what happens when girls get married!

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Why doesn’t anyone care if I get a husband?! Edward puts his hands up, shushing them all.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Emily doesn’t have to marry anyone, as far as I’m concerned.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thank you, Dad. Jesus - at least somebody around here isn’t trying to kick me out of the family.  15.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (to Edward, annoyed) So you’d just let her stay here, in our house, till kingdom come, doing nothing all day--

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I do plenty!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh, like what?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m the one who found all those bird’s nests. She points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corner, on a table, is a HUGE PILE OF BIRD’S NESTS

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: (ending the discussion) All right. It’s time for you ladies to clear out, so I can enjoy my pipe and newspaper in peace. He settles into his armchair. Mrs. Dickinson picks up a t

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Very well. We should get back to the kitchen, anyway. Girls, come with me.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: God, do I have to?!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: (staring at her) You have a shitty attitude, young lady.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to do chores twenty-four hours a day.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: And what would you do instead? Everybody looks at Emily.  16.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I would just - think. Mrs. Dickinson sighs. Edward lights his pipe, and chuckle

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Let her have a break, Mother. It’s all right.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Thanks, Daddy! You’re my hero. She kisses her father on the cheek, and runs out of the r Mrs. Dickinson looks at her husband, coldly.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You just love taking her side, don’t you. Edward shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're going to regret it. She’s wild. She doesn’t know how to behave like a proper young lady. And she’ll be the ruin of this family. With that, Mrs. Dickinson exits. Edward puffs on his pipe EXT. GRASSY AREA — DAY Emily lies face-down on a patch of grass, in the sun, sta at a BUMBLEBEE. The bee is fat, and buzzy, ass-deep in a dandelion. A SHADOW falls over Emily, and the bee. She looks up. It’ her older brother, AUSTIN.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: What up, sis.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (shading her eyes) Nothin’, bro. Just chillin’. Austin, 28, is tall and handsome (think Benjamin Walker, Anders from Workaholics). Secretly, he’s a bit insecure a his intellect -- especially in comparison to his supremel gifted sister.  17.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Heard you turned down another suitor.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yeah. Not into it.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well - on the subject of marriage. I have news. Emily squints up at him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What news?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: I proposed to Sue. And she said yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the back of a hay wagon, Austin is GOING DOWN on his girlfriend, SUE. The wagon jostles violently. Austin’s he is up under Sue’s dress. Sue leans back, eyes closed, in pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes... Austin emerges from under Sue’s skirt, grinning.

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: EXT. GRASSY AREA — CONTINUOUS Emily looks like she’s just been slapped.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. You can’t marry Sue.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Austin, she’s my best friend.  18.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Look, Emily, don’t get crazy right now - it’s not a good time. Sue’s sister Mary is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What?! But she was the healthy one.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: I know. But then she got typhus and died, like all the others. We have to go to the funeral in an hour.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Jesus. Poor Sue.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Yeah. So just - be respectful of her situation, okay?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You don’t have to tell me to be respectful of my best friend.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Be respectful of the woman who is going to be my wife. Austin turns and walks off. Emily stands there, flooded with rage, as a SONG blasts o Taylor Swift, “Bad Blood.”

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR
dialogues.text: “Cause baby now we got bad blood / Hey / Now we got problems...” As the song plays, we see Emily SHRINK DOWN TO THE SIZE O THE BUMBLEBEE.

dialogues.speaker: TAYLOR, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “And I don’t think we can solve them / You made a really deep cut / And baby now we got bad blood!”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily and the BUMBLEBEE sit together on the BRIGHT YELLOW DANDELION, drinking from giant tumblers full of liquor. Emily is WASTED. The BEE is yellow, black, and fuzzy, wit big eyes.  19.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: It’s so obvious what’s going on here. Austin knows I love Sue and he’s trying to steal her from me. He’s such an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: BEE
dialogues.text: (lighting up a joint) Girl, don’t let this relationship shit get in the way of your career.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That's so smart. You’re so right.

dialogues.speaker: BEE
dialogues.text: Just make dat honey, bitch. Make dat honey. He hands her the joint, and she takes a HUGE HIT.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At the funeral of Sue’s sister Mary. A sizable crowd, including all the Dickinsons, stands around the grave as COFFIN gets lowered into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: MINISTER
dialogues.text: (intoning) “O Death, where is thy victory? 0 Death, where is thy sting?” Emily is dressed in white, as always. She looks across th grave and sees SUE, dressed in black. Sue is very, very beautiful -- and very, very sad. She wipes a tear away, and gives Emily a small smile. Emi mouths at Sue: “I love you.” Sue looks down at the grave. The minister wraps up his final prayer and men begin SHOVELING DIRT over the coffin. Emily fights her way through the crowd, trying to get to but just before she reaches her friend’s side, AUSTIN bea her to the punch. He takes Sue by the arm, protectively, leads her off down the hill. Emily stands there, irritated. Funeral guests pass by her all sides, on their way down the hill. Now, Emily looks behind her and sees A STRANGE MAN.  20. The man is tall, with SILVER HAIR, and a GRAY SUIT. He’s attractive, if intense (think Viggo Mortensen). The MAN catches Emily’s eye. He WINKS at her. Just then, LAVINIA appears at her sister’s side. She sees Emily staring into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Emily - what are you looking at? Emily, rapt, points.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: At my friend over there. Lavinia looks where she’s pointing. We see what Lavinia s which is NOTHING.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: What do you mean? That tree? We look again, and once again see what Emily sees - the M who is now walking over towards them.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Never mind, Lavinia. The man comes right over to them. He leans in and whisper into Emily's ear.

dialogues.speaker: MAN
dialogues.text: See you tonight. Emily nods, blushing. The man walks away. Lavinia is confused, but then, she’s used to her sister b weird.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Come on, Emily. Let’s go home. Emily and Lavinia walk together, down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: That was a lovely funeral, don’t you think? Emily shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Mine will be better.  21. As Emily and Lavinia walk, they pass by a GROUP OF GIRLS, well-dressed and well-coiffed. Emily overhears them, gossiping about her.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL
dialogues.text: Oh my god, it’s Emily Dickinson. The girls all titter.

dialogues.speaker: GIRL, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She's so intense. I seriously cannot handle her. Emily pretends not to have heard them. She lifts her chin proudly and marches down the hill with her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Austin and Sue sit on the very stiff couch. Mr. and Mrs. Dickinson sit across from them, on two very stiff armchai They are all in their funeral clothes. Sue’s face is blea

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Well. We are very happy for you. Awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I mean - we’re very sorry about your sister, Sue. But we’re very happy you two shall be wed. Austin smiles. Sue, if it is possible, looks even bleaker

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So, Austin. What are your plans?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Yes, dear, tell us. Austin takes Sue’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well - obviously, nothing is decided yet, but... there is a firm, in Michigan. They have offered me a position. And Sue has a cousin there, so... He trails off. His father stares at him, blankly.  22.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: So what.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: So - we're thinking of moving to Detroit. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m pretty psyched about it, actually. Edward coughs.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I don’t think so. Austin looks at his father, confused.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You'll join my firm, and stay right here in Amherst.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: But - Father, like I just said, I want to go out West...

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Nonsense. We can’t have you living so far. This is Amherst. You are a Dickinson. Your grandfather lived here, and his father before that. Right here in this house. Austin stands up in frustration, and paces to the window. Behind him, OUT THE WINDOW, we notice A WICKER BASKET, th is being lowered down BY A STRING. Austin doesn’t see the basket. He’s flipping out at his d

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Okay - so what do you expect - that Sue and I will get married and live upstairs?!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Of course not. Don’t be absurd. (beat) You’1l live next door.  23.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Next door?! What - in the Irish shanties?! With the stable boys?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Austin, collect yourself. The lot adjacent has come up for sale. I mean to purchase it. We shall build you a house. Austin gapes at his father. Meanwhile, Sue, from the couch, has noticed the BASKET. S points at it, wordlessly.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The most modern, most elegant of houses. You may oversee the design yourselves. It can be built by fall. Consider it a wedding gift. Austin doesn’t know what to say. He looks at Sue, who is pointing at the window.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: What is it, Sue? He turns around, and sees the BASKET. Irritated, he tugs window open, and pulls the basket inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The basket. Which holds AN ENVELOPE. Austin pulls the envelope out. It says: “For Sue.” Austin ignores this. He rips the envelope open. Inside is ANOTHER ENVELOPE. It says: “Austin. Do not read this. Give it to Sue.”

dialogues.speaker: BACK TO
dialogues.text: Austin, aggravated, hands the envelope over to Sue. Sue takes it, opens it, and pulls out a notecard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The notecard. Which says, in Emily’s handwriting: “Meet m the woods.”

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue looks at Austin. He shakes his head. Sue gets up and leaves the room. Austin looks like he wants to punch somebody in the face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Deep in the woods behind the Dickinson house, Emily stand with her arms folded, looking pissed off. Sue comes walking towards her. The two girls face off.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Is this some kind of fucking joke? Sue says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're marrying my brother? Are you insane?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What else was I supposed to do, Emily? My entire family is dead.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I know, and I feel terrible about that, but - Austin?! You don’t even like him! You told me that you don’t respect his intellect. Sue shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And besides, I thought we were never getting married. I thought we were going to grow up and become great writers together.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: That's a stupid promise we made when we were fourteen years old. And even then, I knew it was a lie. I’m not like you, Emily. I didn’t grow up with money. I don’t get to prance around a gorgeous mansion all day and get away with never doing my chores. I don’t have your perfect fucking life.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You think my life is perfect?! Do you even know me?!  25.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: I’m all alone in this world. I’m destitute. If I don’t marry Austin, I will literally starve to death.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: So you're marrying him for his money. Cool. Very cool.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Spoken like a true fucking rich girl. They glare at each other. Then Emily softens.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about Mary. I really liked her.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah. I liked her too. She was my favorite sister.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Well - since you’re marrying Austin - I guess I’1l be your sister now. They look at each other.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Promise me something, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Okay, promise me two things. Sue waits.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Number one, that you won’t move away to Michigan. (Beat.) And number two —

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That you will always love me more than him. For the first time, we see something like a SMILE glimmer over Sue’s face.  26.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well. As far as the first one goes - that’s really Austin’s decision. But as far as the second -—

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: Well, that one’s obvious. I love you so much, Emily. I love you so much, I think I might go to hell for it. A thunderclap. It starts to RAIN. And in the downpour, Em takes Sue into her arms, and KISSES HER. Madly, deeply. The two girls make out furiously in the rain, in the wood Now would be a good time for another great song - maybe something by Lorde? I think you get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the lawn, Austin is playing a game of CROQUET with Geo Emily's suitor. George leans on his MALLET, sipping a glass of SHERRY.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You could have had any girl in town, and you picked Sue Gilbert? Why? Austin lines up a shot, and expertly hits a RED BALL thro a wicket.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: I think it’s because she’s the only one who didn’t want me. George laughs, and takes a shot. He misses.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well - I can relate to that. Your sister is still playing hard to get.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: I'm afraid my sister really is hard to get, old chap. In the sense of, hard to comprehend. She’s a freak.  27.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: She's a genius.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: I'm so sick of people saying that. Austin takes a big whack at a ball. It goes careening off down the slope, and hits a tree. At the same time, EMILY and SUE emerge from the woods. Th are slightly TOUSLED.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello, ladies.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: What are you doing here, George? Austin takes Sue possessively by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Sue - I need to talk to you about something. Sue glances at Emily, and then allows herself to be steer away by Austin. Emily and George are left alone. George, trying to be cool, takes out a pair of 19th-centu wire-framed SUNGLASSES and awkwardly slips them on.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, babe. It’s done. Emily looks at him, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Your poem. It’s in the Indicator. Right next to a thing I wrote about Percy Shelley. The printers have it - it’1l be out next week. (beat) You're a little bit famous now, Emily Dickinson. He grins at her, expecting to see her smile back. Instead, she looks pale, anxious. She bites her fingernai

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Emily? What’s wrong? She shakes her head.  28.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I’m just - scared.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You?! I’ve never seen you scared of anything - you’re absolutely fearless!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I just don’t know how my father will react. George scoffs at this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Seriously - come on. Your dad is a good guy. I know he’s a little conservative - but he loves you. And he’s smart. He has to know how brilliant you are. And that’s not something he’d want to stand in the way of - is it? Emily looks at George, wanting to believe what he’s sayin Then, from the house, she hears Lavinia, SCREAMING.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Emily! EMILY!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lavinia stands outside the door to the kitchen, wearing a APRON, screaming for her sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily nods to George.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I gotta go. She hurries off towards the house - but calls back, over shoulder.  29.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Thanks again, George! George leans on his mallet, and watches her go. He sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pre-dinner CHORES MONTAGE. Fire. Water. Chickens. Emily CUTTING AN ONION, and CRYING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dining room, the whole family sits around the tabl Mother, Father, Emily, Austin, Lavinia, and Sue. The table is laid with beautiful white china, and there’s lots of delicious-looking food. A KITTEN plays at Lavinia’s feet. Edward tears into a piece of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Wonderful chicken, Mrs. Dickinson. Mrs. Dickinson beams.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: It really is delicious, Mother.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Well - thank your sisters. They helped.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: One of us did. Emily pinches Lavinia, under the table. Edward clinks on his glass, with a silver knife.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Now, now, listen here. I have a rather exciting announcement. Everyone looks at him, curious.  30.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As you know, in addition to running my successful law practice, as well as maintaining my position as Treasurer of Amherst College, I’ve also served two terms in the Massachusetts House of Representatives. Well - I’ve got my eye on something bigger now. (beat) I have decided to run for Congress. (beat) Of the United States of America. General shock and awe. Mrs. Dickinson looks a bit queasy.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Father - that’s marvelous!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Holy crap, Dad! Lavinia’s KITTEN, under the table, YOWLS.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I appreciate the enthusiasm. Your mother was quite opposed to the idea.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: I just don’t want you away from home so much. Candidates are always moving about.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Well, we’ve got to get out the vote, now, haven’t we? The vote, and the message.

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: What is your message, Mr. Dickinson?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Mine? Well - it’s simple. Let’s keep the country together, that’s what I say. Let’s not be torn apart.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: You mean - by slavery.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: Father, are you an abolitionist?  31.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Of course not. I don’t care one way or the other about slavery. I just don’t think we ought to go to war about it.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Very sensible, dear.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Personally, I think this Fugitive Slave Act is ridiculous. It’s making us regular citizens into slave-hunting patrols.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You're right about that.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel like a slave. Everyone looks at her, horrified.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You are a spoiled girl from Amherst, Emily Dickinson. Far from a slave. Emily takes a bite of chicken.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Well, it’s a messy business. But we must preserve the Union, at all costs. That’s my platform. Oh - and bring the railroad to Amherst. That too.

dialogues.speaker: LAVINIA
dialogues.text: The railroad! Fancy!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Yes, Lavinia, if I’m elected, you shall hear the sound of a train whistle out your bedroom window!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: That sounds like a nightmare. Sue giggles.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I see I may have a problem convincing some of my constituency.  32. Austin, now, clinks on his glass.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Well, congratulations, Father. And we have an announcement to make as well. Everyone looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sue and I have discussed it - and we will not be moving to Detroit. We're staying here in Amherst - with the family.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hurray!

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh, that’s wonderful, darling.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Excellent, excellent! You can hold the firm together, while I’m off running my campaign. Austin nods, uneasy.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Oh, we'll have a big, lovely wedding! We’ll invite all the Dickinson and Norcross cousins - and Sue, of course, your whole family will come--

dialogues.speaker: SUE
dialogues.text: My whole family is dead. Awkward silence.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Well. (beat) It will still be very nice. Now, suddenly, Emily CLINKS ON HER GLASS.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What is it, Emily?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I also have an announcement. Heads turn to her.  33.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It’s not that big of a deal. I mean, compared to Congress, and getting married, and whatever.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Well, what is it, then? She takes a deep breath.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: A poem I wrote - is going to be published. Next week. In the college magazine. Absolute silence. Deafening, hair-raising silence. Silenc that could crush you. Then, Edward speaks - very low, and icy.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I don’t think I heard you correctly. Say that again. The color goes out of Emily’s face.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: My poem - will be published.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: How. Dare. You. Emily's face gets even more pale, as she realizes how ugl this is going to be.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have I, or have I not, made it quite clear that I do not approve of a woman seeking to build herself a literary reputation? Emily, barely, nods.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And yet you have gone and done it. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well. Is there any way to stop it? Emily, scared, shakes her head.  34.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (quiet) It’s already gone to print. Edward SLAMS HIS FIST DOWN on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: You - wicked - girl! You will bring shame upon this family! Emily looks at her MOTHER, and finds only more disapprova

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (shouting) Your mother was right! We have given you too much freedom - and you have taken advantage of our kindness! Oh, this is a bad time, Emily - a very bad time indeed, that you have chosen to exhibit such scandalous behavior! My god, you will ruin the good name of

dialogues.speaker: DICKINSON
dialogues.text: Again, Edward slams BOTH FISTS down. The plates CLATTER. Everyone besides him and Emily, all at once, GETS UP AND LEAVES THE ROOM. Emily is alone at the big table with her father, and his rage.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Do you not understand, Emily, that we have a reputation to protect in this town? He waits for a response. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Speak to me when I address you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (hoarse) Yes, Father.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: The Dickinsons have lived in Amherst for two hundred years. We made this town what it is. Everyone knows that. (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But your grandfather was a drunk, and a debtor, and he practically squandered everything my ancestors worked so hard to build. I’ve spent my life cleaning up his mess. I’ve scrimped, and sacrificed - and by God's grace, I’ve restored our family to its good standing. And now, I refuse to have my efforts undone BY MY OWN DAUGHTER!!! Another fist-slam on the table.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This - foolishness of yours - we will have no more of it. You will be correct and proper in all your ways. You will tend to your duties, as your mother does. You have much room for improvement, there. Look - I see my plate is chipped. You set the table, didn’t you? Do you give the master of the house a chipped plate? Emily is silent.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Now. As punishment - you will clean up in here. And in the kitchen. Alone. Edward stands up and leaves. 35. Emily waits a moment, by herself. The room is silent. Then, she stands up. Walks around to her father’s Picks up his PLATE. It is, indeed, CHIPPED. Emily stares at the plate for a second. Then, she around and HURLS IT at the STONE FIREPLACE. The plate SHATTERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From a distance, we see Emily waiting outside the the moonlight. She wears an overcoat, and a scarf. A BLACK CARRIAGE pulled by WHITE HORSES rolls up. A HAND reaches out of the carriage. Takes Emily’s steps in. place. turns house, in hand. She  36. The carriage ROLLS AWAY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the carriage, Emily sits across from her companion the STRANGE MAN she saw earlier, at the funeral. This is Emily’s lover. This is DEATH.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: Nice to see you.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: You were late.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: Most people would be glad if I never came.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Not me. I always want to see you. Death smiles at her.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: So, your poem is going to be published.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No. Father won’t allow it.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: I thought you said it was too late to stop it.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Father will burn every copy, if he has to. Anything to prevent me from ruining the good name of Dickinson. Death laughs.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: My dear, you’ll be the only Dickinson they talk about in two hundred years. I promise you that.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Even if my poems are never published?  37.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: Publicity is not the same as immortality.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Immortality is nothing. All it takes is being very good and well- behaved. And then you go to heaven.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: That’s not the kind I mean. Your immortality will not come from following the rules. It will come from breaking them. Emily smiles at him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Today at Mary’s funeral, they said she was going to heaven. Is it true? Death shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: I suppose. She was kind of blah. Emily laughs. Her body relaxes into the seat. She looks a Death, flirtatiously.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: When will you come for me?

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: I come for you every night, my darling.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: No - not just for a ride. To take me away from this place.

dialogues.speaker: DEATH
dialogues.text: Ah. Not for many, many years.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: But you took Mary. Do you love her more than me? Death just laughs. He pats the seat next to him. Emily ge up and squeezes in beside him. The carriage RIDES THROUGH THE DARKENED STREETS OF AMHERS under the moon.  38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily is finishing up the arduous task of cleaning the en kitchen by herself, after dinner. She is sweaty, dirty, and tired. She wipes a hand on her forehead. Some ASHES from the fireplace SMUDGE her brow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Emily trudges upstairs and runs into Austin, in the upsta hallway. He’s in his pajamas.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Another fight with Dad, huh? Emily shakes her head, exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Don't be too hard on him, Em. I know he can be tough - but he only wants to protect us. Emily says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Can I tell you a secret? She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’m happy we’re not moving to Detroit. I feel better here, with the family. Emily gives him a small smile.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hey - do me a favor.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Do what you can - to cheer up Sue. She's so depressed. I’m worried about her.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Sure. Of course.  39.

dialogues.speaker: AUSTIN
dialogues.text: Thanks, sis. The siblings are now interrupted by the appearance of the MOTHER, in her nightgown.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Emily - get to sleep. We need you up bright and early tomorrow. Another suitor is coming.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Oh, great. Who is it this time?

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: A pig farmer, from South Hadley.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Sexy. Austin laughs. Mother shoos them both off to their rooms.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: Go to bed! INT. EMILY’S BEDROOM - NIGHT In the moonlit shadows of her bedroom, Emily sits at her writing desk, by the window. She lights a candle, takes out her pencil, closes her eye and thinks.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: “Because I could not stop for Death...” There is a KNOCK on her door. Startled, she leaps up, BLOWS OUT the candle, and JUMPS I BED, under the covers. Another KNOCK.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (from bed) Who is it? The door opens. Standing in the doorway is her FATHER. He wearing a nightgown himself, and a knitted nightcap.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Emily. Are you awake.  40.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (sitting up) Yes, Father.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: May I come in?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Yes, you may. Edward comes in, shuts the door behind him. He sits down the bed, next to Emily. He waits a beat or two, then speaks.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I was rather gruff with you tonight. Another beat.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'd hate to think that you were angry with me. She says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You just - you can’t know how I worry about you children. He looks at her. Then, unexpectedly, he BREAKS INTO A SOB

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (crying) Oh, Emily!

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (disturbed) Father, what is it! Oh, Father, don’t cry!

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: I just don’t want to lose you, Emmy. Promise me! Promise me, okay?

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Promise you what?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Promise you won't get married and move away.  41. Edward clutches Emily’s hand, and stares at her through h tears. It’s touching, though deeply strange.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: I won’t leave you, Dad. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Oh, that makes me happy. Keep the family together, that’s what I say. Don’t let it get torn apart. Now Edward lies down in Emily’s narrow bed, beside her. H head rests on her pillow. She lies down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Hey Dad. Can you promise me something, too?

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: What is it, my dear? Emily stares up at the ceiling.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: Promise me - that we can hire a maid. Edward, against all his better judgement, laughs.

dialogues.speaker: EDWARD
dialogues.text: Oh, Emily. All right. She grins. He closes his eyes, and within seconds, FALLS ASLEEP. He starts to SNORE. As soon as Emily realizes that he’s sleeping, she careful CLIMBS OUT OF BED, and returns to her WRITING DESK. She sits down AT HER DESK, in the moonlight. She starts t write.

dialogues.speaker: EMILY, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: “Because I could not stop for Death / He kindly stopped for me. / The carriage held but just ourselves / And immortality.” She finishes writing. Punctuates her sentence. Leans back

dialogues.speaker: EMILY
dialogues.text: (to herself) Nailed it.  42. A FINAL BURST OF MUSIC. This time, it’s KANYE. The remix the Daft Punk song, “Stronger.”

dialogues.speaker: KANYE
dialogues.text: “N-n-now that don’t kill me / Can only make me stronger...” We leave Emily, at her desk, and GO OUT THE WINDOW, into night.

dialogues.speaker: KANYE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: “I need you to hurry up now / Cause I can’t wait much longer...” The big Dickinson house glows, eerie, in the moonlight. In the sky, there are thousands of stars. FADE OUT.
